metadata.title: Served with Court Papers / Other Family Law Matters
metadata.description: Guidance for users who were served with court papers or need help with other family law matters

ServedStart.text: You've been served with court papers. Let's help you understand what to do next.

UnderstandPapers.text:
When you receive court papers, it means someone has filed a legal case involving you. The papers will tell you:

• What type of case it is
• What the other person is asking for
• When you need to respond
• When your court date is (if scheduled)

PaperType.text: What type of papers were you served with?

RestrainingOrderServed.text:
If you were served with a restraining order (DVRO, CHRO, etc.), you have important deadlines:

• You may have a Temporary Restraining Order (TRO) that is already in effect
• You must respond by the deadline listed in your papers
• You have the right to go to court and tell your side of the story
• If you don't respond, the court may grant the order against you

DivorceServed.text: If you were served with divorce papers, you have 30 days to file a Response (Form FL-120). You may also want to file a Request for Order if you need temporary orders for custody, support, or property.

CustodyServed.text: If you were served with custody or support papers, you typically have 30 days to file a Response. The papers will tell you the exact deadline.

OtherType.text:
For other types of family law cases, check your papers for:

• The deadline to respond
• What forms you need to file
• When your court date is scheduled

NeedHelp.text: Do you need help understanding your papers or filing a response?

SelfHelpCenter.text:
The Self-Help Center can assist you with:

• Understanding your court papers
• Finding the right forms to file
• Learning about the court process
• Preparing your response

Location: Room 101, First Floor
Hours: Monday-Friday, 8:30 AM - 12:00 PM
Phone: (650) 261-5100 ext. 2

LegalAid.text:
Legal Aid Society of San Mateo County provides free legal assistance to eligible individuals:

• Help understanding your rights
• Assistance with filing responses
• Representation in some cases

Phone: (650) 558-0915

Note: Income eligibility requirements apply

GetQueue.text: A facilitator can help you understand your papers and determine what you need to do next. We'll get you a queue number so you can speak with someone.

QueueGenerated.text: Your queue number has been generated. Please wait to be called. A facilitator will help you understand your court papers and guide you through the next steps.

edges.when: I want to speak with an attorney
